wikipedia_page.main: Walter Cecil Macfarren (28 August 1826 – 20 September 1905) was an English pianist, composer and conductor, and a teacher at the Royal Academy of Music.

response: *August 28 – Walter Cecil Macfarren, pianist and composer
*Walter Cecil Macfarren (1826–1905), English composer of 1 symphony

Edwin H. Lemare was born in Ventnor, on the Isle of Wight on 9 September 1865.Nelson Barden (January 1986) "Edwin H. Lemare", The American OrganistKeller, G., Kruseman, P. (1932) Geïllustreerd Muzieklexicon, p. 390 His birth year is sometimes erroneously stated as 1866, including in Lemare's own autobiography Organs I Have Met. He received his early musical training as a chorister and organist under his father (a music seller, also called Edwin Lemare) at Holy Trinity Church. He then spent three years at the Royal Academy of Music from 1876 on a Goss Scholarship, where he studied under Sir George Alexander Macfarren, Walter Cecil Macfarren, Dr Charles Steggall and Dr Edmund Hart Turpin. He obtained the F.R.C.O. in 1886. He became an organ professor and examiner for the Associated Board of the Royal Schools of Music in 1892.
*Walter Cecil Macfarren (1826–1905), pianist and composer, brother of George Alexander Macfarren, and in whose name the Royal Academy of Music prize is awarded
Their eldest son was Sir George Alexander Macfarren and their youngest Walter Cecil Macfarren.

He was born in Sudbury, Derbyshire in 1812, son of a musician. He entered the Royal Academy of Music in 1822, the year it opened, and he gained two of the first medals given by the Academy, for composition and the piano. He became Sub-professor at the academy in 1826, and later Professor of the Piano, remaining in the post for more than fifty years. His pupils included Charlotte Alington Barnard, William Sterndale Bennett, George Alexander Macfarren, Walter Cecil Macfarren and James William Davison.

Hermann Löhr studied at the Royal Academy of Music, studying piano with Walter Cecil Macfarren and harmony and counterpoint with Frederick Corder. At the academy he won the Charles Lucas medal for composition.Hubert Eisdell – A Discography MusicWeb International. Retrieved 17 May 2018.
